Award.AwardTitle: Sustainable Infrastructure for the SUNY Oneonta Biological Field Station Upper Research Site
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

The proposal seeks funding to renovate biological field station by replacing a laboratory building located on the Upper Research Site of SUNY-Oneonta?s Biological Field Station. The Upper Research Site is located near Moe Pond in New York State and is a relatively remote research area comprising the oldest of the field station?s nearly 1000-ha holdings. The site has been used for studies on primary productivity in old fields undergoing succession, community ecology of anthropophilous mosquitoes, trematode and mollusk life cycles and population dynamics, fisheries ecology, impacts of invasive species, trophic cascades associated with water quality management and land use, and other topics. The field station has a record of supporting research training for women students with women making up 52% of the field station?s student interns over the past four decades.

The structure proposed for replacement is a primitive wood-frame field laboratory, about 5m x 12m. The upgrade to more modern laboratory space will provide researchers with the ability to conduct more sophisticated studies and will allow researchers to establish long-planned projects in ornithology, parasitology, geomorphology, botany, and population ecology. Examples of research projects that would benefit from the renovated facility include: studies of dynamic trophic cascades resulting from alterations in the fisheries in Moe Pond; research on the response of mosquito populations to changes in the nature of the site (e.g. fluctuations in beaver activity); comparison of nutrient runoff from forested lands on acid soils at the Upper Research Site with runoff from primarily agricultural land cover on the more basic soils of the Thayer Farm section of the field station; research on helminth parasites of fishes including a study of the gene flow of C. cornutum and N. rutili in their host populations; Ornithological research including how and why birds sing, the interactive nature of avian communication, breeding behavior, long-term studies of the avian population, and research on the impact of human disturbance on passerine reproductive success; research on cross-biome aquatic carbon biogeochemistry and metabolism.

In addition to providing infrastructure for research, the renovation will provide a resource that will be used by undergraduate and graduate student researchers. It will contribute to the training of graduate students in a new Master of Science in Lake Management program. The renovation will make it possible to extend to the Upper Research Site, the university?s programs of pre-college field experiences and of capstone experiences in the relatively new interdisciplinary major in Environmental Studies. The refurbished laboratory will play a role in long-term ecological studies of the watershed of the upper reaches of the Susquehanna River.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award has effectively enabled faculty and student access to 365 acres of northern and Appalachian hardwoods, red pine, Norway spruce and European larch plantations on the entire watershed of the 30 acre Moe Pond. This site, the Upper Research Site, a gift to SUNY Oneonta in 1968, had been the focus of biological inventories and ecological research, databases maintained with varying intensity since that time. Infrastructure on site was a 16 x 14 frame building constructed to serve as a field lab and shelter for activities conducted on site, accessed by a gravel road opened seasonally.

Since the construction of that original building, the SUNY Oneonta Biological Field Station (BFS) has built or acquired several buildings housing laboratories, classrooms and offices on an additional 2,300 acres. Because access and infrastructure was much improved on the newer sites, and since the original building was inadequate and deteriorating, the Upper Research Site area had been neglected in recent years. The renovations funded through NSF Award No. 0963343 have resulted in a modern, 59m2 (635ft2) laboratory accessible year around via a much improved road. The totally “off the grid” laboratory is powered by a propane generator backed up by a bank of batteries that provides heat, electricity and potable water for a newly drilled well.

Expansion in the capacity of the Upper Research Site will support an extraordinarily diverse group of research projects. Since 1967, the site has been used for studies on primary productivity in old fields undergoing succession, community ecology of anthropophilous mosquitoes, trematode and mollusk life cycles and population dynamics, fisheries ecology, impacts of invasive species, trophic cascades associated with water quality management and land use and other topics, resulting in an extensive publication record. The ability to conduct more sophisticated studies will allow faculty researchers to establish long-planned projects in ornithology, parasitology, geomorphology, botany, and population ecology, and to collaborate with colleagues from other institutions to devise novel investigations capitalizing on the site’s unique characteristics.

This project, while impacting SUNY Oneonta’s BFS and its research projects (most directly by adding bench space and complementing specialized laboratory infrastructure), will provide students at both the undergraduate and graduate levels with richer research experiences, resulting in students who are better-prepared to enter post-graduate studies or positions in the fields of biology, ecology, and environmental science, as well as applied positions in natural resource management. It will also contribute to the training of graduate students in a new Master of Science in Lake Management program. Pre-college field experiences, long offered at the Upper Research Site, but discontinued several years ago as the present laboratory deteriorated, will be resumed. At the present time, over 1,200 students annually are enrolled in similar venues on other BFS lands. By encouraging and supporting a wide range of faculty- and student-driven ecological research projects, the revitalized BFS Upper Research Site will play an important role in long-term ecological monitoring of the watershed of the upper reaches of the Susquehanna River, which drains into the Chesapeake Bay. By providing on-site access, the laboratory will play an important role in the resumption and synthesis of this long-term monitoring, with datasets that will complement nutrient loading and sediment deposition data from other BFS sites used in modeling headwater states’ proposed mitigative responsibility to improve water quality in the Chesapeake Bay.
